block.p: Moscow Meeting Ends Without Defense Accord President Clinton and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia concluded two days of talks with mutual praise and two agreements, but without narrowing the differences over the limited missile defense system the United States wants to erect. Officials described the atmosphere between the two leaders as businesslike, though not necessarily warm.

Security for Barak Increased Israel's secret service has tightened security around Prime Minister Ehud Barak, news media reports say, as some Jewish settlers warn that the domestic climate has the potential to turn ugly if Israeli-Palestinian peace talks move forward.

New Apology in Japan On the eve of elections, Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, was forced to apologize again for controversial comments. His newest comments, using a word for national polity associated with pre-World War II propaganda, recalled his other recent comments in which he called Japan a ''divine country with the emperor at its center.''
Queen Meets Prince's Mistress Queen Elizabeth II, in an unexpected warming, met Camilla Parker Bowles, mistress to her son Charles, the Prince of Wales, for the first time since their affair began.
Report on Life Expectancy The United States falls behind almost every country in Europe in what the World Health Organization calls ''healthy life expectancy,'' according a new report.

Vigil for Tiananmen Protests Eleven years after China turned its tanks and troops against students in Tiananmen Square, about 30,000 people gathered at a candlelight vigil in Hong Kong to remember the doomed democracy movement.

Quake Rocks Sumatra An earthquake and several strong aftershocks hit the island of Sumatra, causing widespread damage and deaths. The death toll was expected to rise as emergency workers search ruined buildings.

A Call for Independence Separatists in the province of West Papua, ignoring stern warnings from the government in Jakarta, made a declaration of independence, in hopes of following the lead of East Timor, which broke away from Indonesia last year.

Chinese Phone Plan Dropped China's second telephone carrier, China Unicom, confirmed that it had abandoned plans to use wireless telephone standards developed by Qualcomm of the United States. It said it could not risk investing in technology that might soon be obsolete.

Fiji Rebel Holds Talks The rebel leader who took over Fiji's Parliament said that he had reached a level of trust with the new military government in discussions, but did not say when he might free more than 30 hostages.

Fierce Campaigns Signal New Era for State Judges Contests for state judgeships around the country have become bruising multimillion-dollar political affairs that critics say are threatening the independence of the nation's state courts.

Judge Trades on Renown Political observers in Alabama say Judge Roy S. Moore, who refused to remove the Ten Commandments from his courtroom, just might win his race to be chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court. Judge Moore's campaign against three Republican opponents is the latest battle for party supremacy between the religious right and the business community in Alabama.

Satellite Plunges Into the Sea The Compton Gamma Ray Observatory was deliberately slammed into the atmosphere, where it shattered before falling in a shower of hot metal into the Pacific Ocean. NASA engineers directed the observatory through a series of suicide rocket firings that dropped it from a high orbit and sent it plunging to Earth. It was NASA's first planned and controlled crash of a satellite.
Parrots Far From Home A flock of wild parrots is thriving in Brownsville, Tex., at least a hundred miles from their typical roosting grounds deep in Mexico.

Turning Ad Issue Back on Gore Democrats are hinting that they may soon begin an advertising campaign on behalf of Vice President Al Gore -- just two and a half months after Mr. Gore proposed a ban on such ''issue ads'' paid for with unregulated soft money. And the Republicans are trying to paint Mr. Gore as a hypocrite even before the first commercial hits the airwaves.

Gore Agrees to Rental Repairs Tenants of a house owned by Vice President Al Gore say their repeated complaints about overflowing toilets and backed up sinks finally a drew a response when Mr. Gore called on Saturday to promise repairs. His response came after the tenants contacted a local television station.

Blocking Gun Sales Background checks blocked 204,000 of the 8.6 million prospective gun sales last year, according to a Justice Department report that shows that state and local police rejected a higher percentage of would-be gun buyers than the F.B.I.
Mary Jenkins Langston The cook for Elvis Presley for 14 years who served him meatloaf, banana icebox pie and his beloved fried peanut butter and banana sandwiches, she was 78.

E.P.A. Poised to Order Cleanup for PCB's A long tug of war between environmental officials and the General Electric Company over what, if anything, to do about the Hudson River's last big chemical stain is almost over. The E.P.A. appears poised to order a cleanup of what it calls a persistent threat to people and wildlife: the polychlorinated biphenyls that lace the river bottom north of Albany and contaminate many kinds of fish throughout the river.

Parade Turns Political Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio stood side by side at New York City's annual Salute to Israel parade. The division within the Jewish community over the United States Senate candidates was starkly on display, and some organizers said the political jockeying overshadowed the purpose of the event.

Arrests in Cockfighting Ring Nearly 200 people were charged after the police raided a neglected movie theater in the Bronx and broke up a professional cockfighting ring as a night of gambling was getting started, the authorities said.
Man Stops Subway Pushing A good samaritan stopped a man from pushing a woman onto the subway tracks in Morningside Heights and held him until officers arrived, the police said.

2000 Tony Awards ''Copenhagen'' won the Tony for best play and ''Kiss Me, Kate'' won for best musical revival. And Michael Blakemore won the best director award for the play and the musical. Rosie O'Donnell was host of the ceremony.
Lakers Win Finals The Los Angeles Lakers beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 89-84, to win the Western Conference finals.
Derby Winner Out of Belmont The Kentucky Derby winner, Fusaichi Pegasus, was injured and will not race in the Belmont Stakes.

Another Outburst From Rocker The Braves had to deal with another outburst from John Rocker -- this time against Jeff Pearlman, the Sports Illustrated reporter who had quoted Mr. Rocker attacking people with AIDS, welfare mothers, minorities, people who speak foreign languages in the United States, and other urban types in an article last year.

Schwab Plans Wireless Link Charles Schwab, the leading discount brokerage firm, plans to let online customers cut the cord and do their online trading from cars or even the beach, using wireless devices.

British Air Talks With KLM British Airways has held informal merger discussions with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, said executives close to both companies said. The talks, which are in the most preliminary stage, underscore a sense of urgency among airline operators to seek partners, in the hope of increasing profit.

I.B.M. Has Deal With Start-Up I.B.M. and the start-up company Salesforce.com plan to announce a partnership today aimed at helping small businesses transform themselves into e-businesses. I.B.M. would make the Salesforce service -- which offers software for managing sales information -- available to customers of its Small Business WebConnections.

Talks for Chello Stake Telewest Communications, Britain's second-largest cable television company, is expected to announce as early as this week that it will acquire a stake of about 10 percent in Chello Broadband, executives close to the talks said. Chello provides high-speed access to the Internet across Europe.

Digital Film Distribution On Tuesday, for the first time, a Hollywood movie will go from the studio to a theater without ever touching film, officials at 20th Century Fox and Cisco Systems said. The movie, ''Titan A.E.,'' will be digitally transmitted across the country over the Internet and then digitally projected to a cinema audience.
